summary: The All India Railway Parcel and Goods Porters Union praying for the following reliefs: "a) Issue appropriate writ in the nature of mandamus or any other writ, direction or order commanding the respondents to treat the petitioners who are working as Parcel Porters as permanent employees of the Northern Railway as has been directed by this Hon'ble Court in various petitions filed by the colleagues of the petitioners and a further direction may be given to abolish contract system in parcel handling work at different Railway Stations in Northern Railway and all the Parcel Porters working at different Railway Stations of Norther Railway may be treated as regular employees of the Railways." Parcel Porters working as contract labour at different railway stations have been treated as permanent employees of Northern Railways, the High Court of Judicature at Allahabad has ruled. The learned counsel has submitted that the petitioners have been working as Parcel Porters in the Northern Railway for the past 40 years and they have been discharging the work of permanent and perennial nature.

summary: A writ petition has been filed in the Supreme Court of India against an order of the Jammu and Kashmir High Court quashing the selection of two Munsiffs and granting them selection grade and super-time scale. On 27.4.2002, the High Court of Andhra Pradesh by an order No. Heard, the third respondent was placed in the super-time scale applying the norms formulated by the High Court, which are also the matter of challenge in these proceedings. A Division Bench of the Jammu and Kashmir High Court, headed by Justice Tashi Rabstan, has reserved its order on a petition by a group of senior judges of the state challenging a decision of the High Court to appoint them on the basis of selection grade/super-time scale.

summary: This appeal is filed against the judgment of the High Court of Punjab & Haryana at Chandigarh. The appellant, Hindustan Petroleum Corpn., Haryana, has challenged the order of the CPC, Haryana, suspending the sales and supply of petroleum products to the respondent for a period of 30 days and imposing a penalty of Rs.15,000/- for the said irregularities committed by the respondent as per the appellant's letter dated 16.1.2002. The learned counsel appearing for the appellant contended that the arbitration clause found in the Dealership Agreement could not have contemplated an adjudication by an arbitrator in regard to a dispute arising between the parties pertaining to short- delivery of Motor Spirit and HSD or the tampering with the weights and measurement seals because such dispute can only be adjudicated in a manner provided for under the Standards of Weights and Measures (Enforcement) Act, 1985 (the 1985 Act), and such dispute cannot be sustained because these are the disputes which have consequences, hence, could only be tried by a competent criminal court on being investigated by an authorised agency as provided in the 1985 Act.

summary: The Supreme Court of India on 27 October, 2003 granted leave to the Municipal Corporation of Greater Bombay to appeal against the Single Judge's decision of the Bombay High Court on 27 October, 2003 in the Motor Accidents Claims Tribunal for Greater Bombay (for short the 'Tribunal') adjudicating a claim petition under Section 110-A of the Motor Vehicles Act, 1939 (in short the 'Act'). summary: The High Court of India has held that Banphool Oil is classifiable as an "Ayurvedic Medicament". Reliance was placed in the case of Baidyanath Ayurved Bhawan v Collector of Central Excise, New Delhi reported in [2003] 3 SCC 111. A hair-oil is not a hair-oil merely because it is manufactured and sold by a person dealing in medicines and according to a process more complex than used in the manufacture of ordinary hair-oil.

summary: Appeal by the State of Uttar Pradesh against the judgment of the Division Bench of Allahabad High Court dated 30.11.1998 whereby the Sales Tax Officers Gr.II [now re-designated as 'Trade Tax Officers'] have been directed to be fixed in the revised pay scale of Rs. 690-1420/- with consequential further revision of pay in accordance with the pay revision recommended by Second U.P. summary: The Reserve Bank of India has questioned the correctness of the judgment of the Division of the High Court of Bombay at Nagpur Bench holding that the employees were entitled to pension in terms of the Reserve Bank of India Pension Regulations, 1990 Regulation 26 of the Reserve Bank of India (Amended with effect from 7.2.1992): (1) An employee shall retire at 60 years of age but no extension shall be given to any employee beyond 60 years of age; Provided that an employee who attains the age of superannuation on any day other than the first during a calendar month, shall retire on the last day of that month. summary: Supreme Court of India Public interest litigation has become a tool in the hands of unscrupulous litigants to harass, abuse and harass their targets. summary: Appeal by Rame Gowda (D) against the judgment and decree of the Trial Court, upheld by the High Court, restraining him from interfering with the possession and enjoyment of the suit schedule property by the respondent. The law of possession in India, as it has developed, accords with the jurisprudential thought as propounded by Salmond. 1924 PC 144, Sir John Edge summed up the Indian law by stating that in India persons are not permitted to take forcible possession; they must obtain such possession The Supreme Court of India has held that "a person in peaceful possession of property, even on the assumption that he had no right to remain on the property, he cannot be dispossessed by the owner of the property except by recourse to law".

summary: The Supreme Court of India has been asked to decide whether a tenant who died in 1974 and left her properties to her son should get them back or not. This is an appeal from the High Court of Karnataka against its judgment and decree dated 11.3.1993 in a suit brought by the first plaintiff against the defendant No.1. It was submitted that having regard to the fact that the Will Claude Pinto, Original Defendant No.1, died on 15.12.1988 and having regard to the fact that the legatees had been brought on record as his legal representatives in respect whereof the Trial Court held that the suit did not abate, the High Court committed a manifest error in holding that it was obligatory on the part of the plaintiffs to approach the District Judge for appointment of another of the Will in view of Section 21(1) of the Indian Succession Act.

summary: Citations: The appellants appealed against the acquittal of them by the trial Court and the High Court on the ground that notice of demand was not served on the respondent in accordance with law. The offence of dishonoured cheque under Section 138 of the Indian Penal Code (IPC) can be completed only with the concatenation of a number of acts. The following are the acts which are components of the said offence : (1) drawing the cheque by a person on account maintained by him with a banker, for payment to another person from out of that account for discharge in whole/part any debt or liability, (2) presentation of the cheque by the payee or the holder in due course to the bank, (3) returning the cheque unpaid by the drawee bank for want of sufficient funds to the credit of the drawer or any arrangement with the banker to pay the sum covered by the cheque, (4) giving notice in writing to the drawer of the cheque within 15 days of the receipt of information by the payee from the bank regarding the return of the cheque as unpaid demanding payment of the cheque amount, (5) failure of the drawer to make payment to the payee or the holder in due course of the cheque, of the amount covered

summary: The Court of Appeal for the Central Excise and Gold (Control) Appellate Tribunal is the highest court of appeal in India. The Central Excise Act, 1944 (l of 1944) created no authority for imposition of penalty. In a split judgement, the Supreme Court has held that the power to impose penalty in the nature of an additional or penal tax can be conferred on the State Legislatures as and when they decide to do so.

summary: The Supreme Court of India has given its verdict in the case of Oriental Insurance Company Ltd against Devireddy Konda Reddy and Ors. The Supreme Court of India has held that an insurer is not liable to pay compensation to gratuitous passengers who are injured in a goods vehicle. The new Insurance Act of India mandates compulsory coverage against death of or bodily injury to any passenger of "public service vehicle" or "goods vehicle", except where the vehicle is a vehicle in which passengers are carried for hire or reward or by reason of or in pursuance of a contract of employment, to cover liability in respect of the death of or bodily injury to persons being carried in or upon or entering or mounting or alighting from the vehicle at the time of the occurrence of the event out of which a claim arises."

summary: The Supreme Court of India has ruled that a Sessions Judge who convicted and sentenced a man to undergo RI for a period of one year and fined him with a find of Rs.2 each, was wrong to have held that one of the accused by named was not guilty of the offence charged against him and him while he convicted the other accused including the appellant herein for offences under 302 read with Section 34 IPC and directed them to undergo imprisonment for life and to pay a find of Rs.2 each. The prosecution has failed to establish its case against the appellant and the courts below have mechanically proceeded to record conviction of the appellant. The prosecution has failed to prove its case against the appellant Bimla Devi.

summary: Appeal by the Government of West Bengal against an order of the Calcutta High Court quashing the pay-scale recommended by the First pay commission of the state of west Bengal. The Division Bench of the High Court of West Bengal has held that operators-cum-Mechanics who hold diploma in engineering should be paid the same as those who hold diploma in engineering. The High Court of West Bengal passed the impugned judgment in the case of Nazimuddin Ahmed (supra) in which it was held that "the order passed in the first writ petition filed by Nemai Chand Ghose could not be treated as a precedent as the said judgment was subject to the order passed in the first writ petition filed by Nemai Chand Ghose".

summary: The case was heard by the Special Judge appointed under the Special Courts (Trial of Offences relating to Transactions in Securities) Act, 1992. Standard Chartered Bank (SCB) is the plaintiff in this case and it is seeking recovery of its investment in Government of India securities of the face value of Rs. 42 crores and Rs. 8 crores against receipt of the purchase price paid by the SCB to the Citi Bank. Standard Chartered Bank's (SCB) claim in the Federal Court at New York for recovery of the aforesaid amount due towards the GOI 2009 Bonds is based on the fact that on 17th June, 1991 SCB addressed their advocate's letter to the Citi Bank calling upon the Citi Bank to forthwith handover to SCB the consideration of Rs. 44.8505 crores paid to the Citi Bank with further interest in respect of the said bonds as they had not received delivery of the said bonds from CMF in spite of the lapse of over nine months from the date of giving of the SGL of CMF.

summary: Two separate appeals have been heard in the Supreme Court of India on the issue of whether or not medicated cough drops and throat drops manufactured by the appellants in accordance with and under the licence issued under the Drugs and Cosmetics Act, 1940 are classifiable as ayurvedic drugs for the purpose of levy of central excise duty. A Division Bench of the Supreme Court headed by the Vice-President, while disposing of the appeal of Shri Baidyanath Ayurved Bhawan Private Limited (supra), held that the appellants' claim as Ayurvedic medicine under sub-heading 3003.30 should not be treated as patent or proprietary medicine attracting duty at 15 % ad hoc. The appellants have moved this Court against the order of the Collector of Central Excise, Hyderabad, dismissing their appeal against the classification of their cough drops and throat drops as patent or proprietary medicines.

A Division Bench of the Supreme Court has ruled that acquisition of a school building by the State of Andhra Pradesh under Section 4(1) of the Rent Control and Eviction Act is "not fair and it is only an attempt to scuttle a valid decree passed by the Civil Court which amounts to 'malice in law'". summary: Appeal by Ram Ashrey Singh & Anr from the Division of the Allahabad High Court against the order of termination of their services. On 4.1.1978, the appellant filed an appeal against the order of the High Court which had fixed the back wages at Rs.30,000/-. The Court of Appeal in the case of Ram Ashrey Singh & Anr vs Ram Bux Singh & Ors held: "Payment of back wages having a discretionary element involved in it has to be dealt with in the facts and circumstances of each case and no straight-jacket formula can be evolved, though, there is statutory sanction to direct payment of back wages in its entirety."

summary: Appeal (civil) 879 of 2000 PETITIONER: Bimlesh Tanwar RESPONDENT: State of Haryana and Ors. The Haryana High Court has held that the names of candidates who qualified in the examination held in December, 1988 should be entered in the register maintained therefor as envisaged by Rule 1 of Part- D of the Rules and to fill up the existing vacancies and also the vacancies, which are anticipated to arise during the period of 2 years from the date of publication of the result of the examination, i.e., up to December, 1991. The appellants were recommended by a Sub-committee appointed by the High Court of Haryana and accepted by the Full Court of the High Court by adopting a resolution in that behalf on or about 17.7.1997.

summary: The Central Board of Secondary Education has appealed against the decision of the Madhya Pradesh High Court directing it to declare the result of the high school examination of class X in the year 1996. In the year 1996, the Delhi High Court was hearing a petition challenging the decision of the Delhi School Education Board (DSEB) to admit a student to Class X. Aftger quoting bye-law 10.2 the High Court held that the private candidates under bye-law no. 10.2, namely, a student must have secured higher than 'E' grade in each subject of internal assessment and has also passed the third language as per requirement laid down in the scheme.

summary: Appeal by Deb Narayan Halder against the judgment and order of the High Court of Judicature at Calcutta in CRR No. 973 of 2001 whereby the High Court while allowing the Revision Petition preferred by the respondent directed appellant to pay a sum of Rs.1CR per month by way of maintenance to the respondent and also to pay costs. In her application, the respondent stated that she and the appellant had been married for 10 years and she had no source of income. summary: The Supreme Court of India has held that the work of the employees for maintaining supply of electricity in the College and Hospital premises being a perennial nature, the Engineering Department of Chandigarh Administration be directed to regularise their services. summary: The appellants appeal against the conviction and sentence of life imprisonment and three-year jail term given to them by the Additional Sessions Judge, Amravati, Maharashtra, for the offences punishable under the Indian Penal Code, 149. Learned counsel for the accused-respondents submitted that the High Court was correct in holding that Section 149 IPC was applicable to the facts of the case.

summary: Two appeals have been made by Ayyar Thavar and Porutchyelvan against their conviction and sentence for the murder of Maheswari, the wife of Azagu Raja. On 3.12.1991, at about 2.00 p.m., Maheswari, a resident of Sethupathi in Tirunelveli district, went out to meet her lover Azagu Raja at his house and was attacked by four members of her family including Krishnan, Ganesan, Porutchyelvan and Ayyar Thavar. Counsel for accused-appellants Krishnan and Ganesan submitted that the prosecution case against them is not fit to be held guilty of offence punishable under Section 302 IPC as the ingredients of Section 34 IPC are not made out.

summary: Appeal by Navjot Sandhu against his conviction by a special court in Delhi for plotting to attack the Parliament of India in 2001. In the recent past the trial courts in India have been finding it difficult to dispose of cases because of the delay in disposing of cases due to objections raised during the evidence-collecting stage. On 9 May, 2003 appellant Syed Abdul Rehman Geelani and appellant Navjot Sandhu filed applications before the Special Judge (POTA), New Delhi seeking quashing of the order dated 11th July, 2002 of the Special Judge.

summary: Appeal by Baitarani Gramiya Bank against the impugned judgment and order of the High Court of Orissa. The Baitarini Gramiya Bank had intimated vacancies in the posts of Field Supervisors and Officers to the Bangladesh State Reserve Bank (BSRB) on 28.11.1988. A Division Bench of the Tamil Nadu High Court has ruled that a selected candidate does not acquire an indefeasible right of appointment in view of what has been held by a Constitution Bench in Shankarsan Dash v Union of India, AIR (1991) SC 1612, which was followed by a three Judge Bench decision in Dilbagh Singh, AIR (1993) SC 16, but the Scheme of selection of the Officers and other employees of the regional rural Banks, to which we have referred, which requires examination of the matter by a centralised agency (the Board) and which permits giving of option and visualises preparation of a select list as per descending order of merit, would clothe a selectee higher up in the merit list with a right to demand appointment if a person lower in the list has been appointed in any other Bank, any other view would denude his fundamental right available by the force of Article 16 of the Constitution.

summary: Appeal by Lalit Popli against an order of the Delhi High Court dismissing his appeal against his dismissal from service for misconduct. The Enquiry Officer of Canara Bank issued the following letter to an employee of the bank: "It is evident that you by misusing your official position, in collusion with someone else, got the above said cheque book issued in S.B. A/c no.4272, utilised the cheque leaves in question by forging the signature of the account holder and got the same presented to encash the cheques fraudulently. The appellant-employee has challenged the decision of the Division Bench of the High Court to uphold the disciplinary proceedings against him.

summary: Appeal by special leave against the judgment of the Division Bench of Delhi High Court allowing Civil Writ Petition (PIL)No.5646/2000 and Civil Writ Petition No.2802/2000. The governments of India and Mauritius, under the provisions of this Agreement, are defined as the " Contracting States". summary: The appellants appeal against the conviction and sentence passed by the Sessions Court in Ranchi for murder of Suphal Hansda on 21st June, 1987 in Jharkhand. The first set of witnesses consists of PWs. The third set of witnesses consists of PWs 6, 7 & 8 who reached the place of occurrence after receiving information of the incident having taken place and found Suphal Hansda lying dead at the place of occurrence. The Supreme Court has held that the testimony of a single witness cannot be classified as wholly reliable or wholly unreliable.

summary: The appellants have challenged the validity of section 80 P (2) (a) (iii) of the Income Tax Act, 1961 and grant of deduction of the profits made by societies by the marketing of agricultural produce. Section 80P (2) (a) (iii) of the Income Tax Act provides for deduction of profits of co-operative societies engaged in marketing agricultural produce "produced by its members". The National Agricultural Co-Operative Society of India and Ors challenged an amendment to the Income Tax Act which seeks to exclude all cooperative societies except the primary society from the benefit of Section 80 P(2)(aiii) of the Income Tax Act.

summary: The Nagpur bench of the Bombay High Court has listed a case for hearing on 17 April, 2003. Section 115 of the Code of Civil Procedure (Amendment) Act, 1976 provides that the High Court may call for the record of any case which has been decided by any Court subordinate to the High Court and in which no appeal lies thereto, and if such subordinate court appears (a) to have exercised a jurisdiction not vested in it by law, or (b) to have acted in the exercise of its jurisdiction illegally or with material irregularity. Section 115 of the Indian Penal Code (IPC) was amended by the Old Amendment Act in 1976.

summary: The case has been referred to the Supreme Court of India. A charge sheet has been drawn up against a Border Security Force (BSF) officer in connection with a case of corruption in the force. The learned Single Judge of the Himachal Pradesh High Court, Shimla, in his judgment dated 7 March, 2003 held that the findings of guilt arrived at by the General Security Force Court in the case of M.S. Arya was not within the domain of the High Court exercising its jurisdiction under Article 226 of the Constitution of India having regard to the settled principle of law that it does not exercise any power of superintendence over the Courts constituted under the Army Act, BSF Act and in that view of the matter it could not have reappreciated the evidence.

summary: Appeal (civil) 3946 of 2001 PETITIONER: Public Services Tribunal Bar Association RESPONDENT: State of U.P. The Public Services Tribunals Act was enacted by the Parliament under Article 323-A of the Constitution providing a Central Administrative Tribunal with benches for adjudicating disputes in respect of recruitment and conditions of service of persons appointed under the Central Government and its undertakings in connection with the affairs of the Union. Section 6 (7) of the Public Services Tribunal Act, 1990 was replaced by the Administrative Tribunals Act, 1985.

summary: This is an appeal against the judgment and order dated 26 September 2003 of the Delhi High Court, which held that a Jain Society registered under the Letter Administration Act, 1860, was not entitled to protection of orphans. Under the provisions of the Indian Succession Act, 1983, a letter of administration or probate can only be granted to those who are named in Sections 223 and 236 of the Act. Courts in India have held that a society is not entitled to administration of an estate.

summary: The Supreme Court of India is hearing three separate appeals challenging the constitutional validity of the Central Administrative Tribunals Act, 1985 and the panel prepared for the post of Vice-Chairman in various branches of the Central Administrative Tribunal in India and seeking for preparation of a fresh panel. The Delhi High Court has ruled that the Vice-Chairman of the Central Administrative Tribunal (CAT) should be from amongst the persons having judicial training. We are of the view that the High Court has overstepped its jurisdiction in issuing further directions to the Secretary, Law Department, Union of India, the secretary Personnel and Appointment Department, Union of India, the Cabinet Secretary of Union of India and to the Chief Secretary of the U.P.

summary: The judgments of the High Court of Judicature at Allahabad are available on the website of the Supreme Court of India. The High Court of Kerala has held that the right to use the whole system of the telephone exchange was not transferred to the subscriber by the Department of Telecommunications (DoT) under the Indian Telegraph Act, 1885 and the Rules made thereunder. Section 3F of the Central Sales Tax Act, 1956, imposes on every dealer, for each assessment year, the liability to pay a tax inter alia, on the net turnover of transfer of 'the right to use any goods', for any purpose, whether or not for a specified period, for cash, deferred payment or other valuable consideration.

summary: Amiya Bala Paul vs Commissioner of Income Tax, Shillong The Commissioner of Income Tax has challenged an order of the Shillong High Court which had held that the Valuation Officer appointed under the Wealth Tax Act 1957 could not give a valuation report in respect of any matter not covered by the provisions of that Act. Under section 16 A of the Income Tax Act, 1961, the Valuation Officer may, under sub-section (2) of section 16 A, estimate the value of an asset in respect of which a requisition has been made to him.

summary: Appeal from the High Court of Karnataka. summary: The Supreme Court of India has given its verdict in the case of Tulshidas Kanolkar, convicted of raping and murdering a mentally disabled woman in Goa in 2003. The High Court of Bombay at Goa has upheld the conviction of a man for raping a mentally challenged girl but reduced the sentence to 7 years in relation to the offence punishable under Section 376 IPC. The Goa High Court has dismissed the appeal of Tulsidas Kanolkar, convicted and sentenced to three-and-a-half years in jail for physically and mentally abusing her daughter.

summary: The appellant Kheraj Ram has been convicted and sentenced to life imprisonment for the murder of his wife, two children and brother-in-law. The appellant Kheraj Ram was convicted and sentenced to death by the High Court of Rajasthan for the murder of his wife Amru, his two daughters, and her friend Kannu. It is trite law that when a case rests upon circumstantial evidence, such evidence must satisfy the following tests: (1) the circumstances from which an inference of guilt is sought to be drawn, must be cogently and firmly established; (2) those circumstances should be of a definite tendency unerringly pointing towards guilt of the accused; (3) the circumstances, taken cumulatively should form a chain so complete that there is no escape from the conclusion that within all human probability the crime was committed by the accused.

summary: Appeal by Indian Handicrafts Emporium & Ors vs Union of India & Ors. summary: The appellant Raja Ram was convicted and sentenced to death by a Sessions Court in Hanumangarh, Rajasthan for the murder of five members of a family on 20.12.1989. The appellant-accused has challenged the acquittal of him by the Madhya Pradesh High Court on the ground that the prosecution failed to establish that he alone was responsible for the crime. It is trite law that when a case rests upon circumstantial evidence, such evidence must satisfy the following tests: "(1) the circumstances from which the conclusion of guilt is sought to be drawn, must be cogently and firmly established; (2) those circumstances should be of a definite tendency unerringly pointing towards guilt of the accused; and (3) the circumstances, taken cumulatively should form a chain so complete that there is no escape from the conclusion that within all human probability the crime was committed by the accused and none else."

summary: Appeal by Roshanlal Agarwal & Ors against the order of the Special Court (Economic Offences) dismissing their plea for discharge. The appellant has challenged the order of the High Court of Delhi which held that the Special Court set up under the Imports and Exports (Control) Act, 1947 could not try any other offence including that under the Indian Penal Code. The genesis of this case can be traced back to 1982 when the State Government of Karnataka vide a notification issued in exercise of power conferred by proviso to sub-section (1) to Section 11 of the Code of Criminal Procedure, 1973, (Central Act 2 of 1974) created a Special Court (Economic Offences), Bangalore Metropolitan Area and the District of Bangalore for the trial of offences under the Acts specified in the schedule having jurisdiction within the local area of the revenue district of Bangalore including the Bangalore Metropolitan area.

summary: The entire exercise which culminated in the impugned judgment of the High Court, in our opinion, was an exercise in futility and sheer waste of time and money. The High Court of Bombay has quashed the order of the Sessions Judge framing charge under section 304 Part II, IPC against Salman Salim Khan and directed the appropriate Magistrate's court to frame de novo charges under various sections mentioned in the said impugned order. We are of the opinion that the impugned judgment of the High Court in the case of Salman Salim Khan and Anr is not justified in this case.

summary: Appeal by P.V. Radhakrishna against his conviction and sentence for uxoricide by the 22nd City Civil and Sessions Judge, Bangalore. The appellant challenged the conviction on the basis of dying declaration recorded by a police officer. A dying declaration is a statement made by a person in a fit state of mind, who has no power of oath or cross-examination.

summary: All references are copyrighted. The High Court of Maharashtra and Ors has ruled that the State is not liable to pay interest on the rental compensation paid to the owners of the land under the Maharashtra Land Reforms Act. The Court of Appeal in Maimuma Banu and Ors has held that the Maharashtra Land Acquisition Act does not provide for payment of rental compensation.
